questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with hypertension, chest pain, and cramping of the legs. A chest radiograph was taken which revealed the condition as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Coarctation of aorta Explanation: The presence of the Figure of 3 sign and rib notching on X-ray, along with symptoms of hypertension and chest pain, indicates coarctation of the aorta . These findings suggest narrowed aorta leading to collateral circulation and rib erosion, confirming the diagnosis. Figure of 3 sign: This sign indicates a contour abnormality of the aorta commonly associated with coarctation of the aorta.

questions.question: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: heart" (coeur en sabot) seen on a chest radiograph is a classic finding in TOF. It occurs due to: Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which causes the apex of the heart to lift upward. Pulmonary artery hypoplasia or stenosis, which accentuates the shape. TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, characterised by the four features: Pulmonary stenosis Right ventricular hypertrophy Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Overriding aorta Chest X-ray Imaging in TOF: The classic finding on a chest X-ray for TOF is the “boot-shaped” heart (also known as coeur en sabot ), caused by right ventricular hypertrophy leading to an upward tilt of the cardiac apex. There is often a concave main pulmonary artery and decreased pulmonary vascular markings , reflecting the reduced blood flow through the pulmonary arteries due to the RVOT obstruction. Some patients may also present with a right-sided aortic arch , which can be identified on the X-ray. Ebstein’s anomaly (option B): This is incorrect because the radiographic finding in Ebstein’s anomaly is an enlarged, "box-shaped" heart due to massive right atrial enlargement, not a boot shape. Transposition of great arteries (TGA) (option C): This is incorrect because TGA typically shows an "egg-on-string" appearance on chest X-ray, with a narrow mediastinum. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) (option D): This is incorrect because TAPVC commonly shows a "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign due to dilated veins and a vertical vein, not a boot-shaped heart.

questions.question: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Left Atrium Explanation: In cardiac CT imaging , the left atrium is best visualized posteriorly, near the esophagus. It receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins and is located at the posterior aspect of the heart , superior to the left ventricle. Cardiac Chambers on CT Imaging Chamber Location on CT Key Features Right Atrium Anterior, right side Receives deoxygenated blood from IVC/SVC Right Ventricle Most anterior chamber Lies close to the sternum, pumps blood to pulmonary artery Left Atrium Posterior aspect Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins Left Ventricle Left, inferior Thickest-walled chamber, pumps blood into aorta Right Atrium (Option A): Incorrect because it is anterior and right-sided , whereas the left atrium is posterior. Right Ventricle (Option B): Incorrect because it is the most anterior chamber , located near the sternum. Left Ventricle (Option C): Incorrect because it is larger and more inferior , with thick muscular walls for systemic circulation. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3096290/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4090749/

questions.question: In what situation is popcorn calcification observed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pulmonary Hamartoma Explanation: Popcorn calcification is a characteristic finding on imaging, particularly CT scans , seen in pulmonary hamartomas . These are benign tumors of the lung, typically composed of cartilage, fat, and connective tissue. The calcifications often appear as popcorn-like due to the presence of calcified nodules or cystic components within the tumor. Pulmonary hamartoma Hamartomas are the most common benign lung tumors, Generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally Radiographic Features: Typically present as a solitary peripheral pulmonary nodule or mass. Size usually ranges from 1 to 4 cm. Well-circumscribed, round or oval shape with smooth or lobulated margins. Internal calcifications, often with a "popcorn" appearance CT scans effectively reveal internal fat , which is pathognomonic for hamartomas. Hamartomas may be multiple, grow slowly, and do not cavitate or invade adjacent structures. Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option A): Incorrect because Hodgkin’s lymphoma may cause mediastinal masses but does not exhibit popcorn calcifications typically. Calcifications in lymphoma are more uniform and fine. Metastasis (Option C): Incorrect because metastatic lesions usually present as irregular nodules with variable densities. They do not typically show popcorn-like calcifications. Fungal Ball (Option D): Incorrect because fungal balls can calcify, but these calcifications are not typically of the popcorn type . They are more likely to appear as heterogeneous or mottled calcifications. Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology 7th Edition, Page 117, 118 David Sutton Textbook of Radiology & Imaging 8th Edition, Volume 1, Page 265,1056

questions.question: Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicated pathology involving which of the following structures? [
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Right Middle Lobe Explanation: On a chest X-ray , the right cardiac border is formed by the right atrium . The silhouette sign helps localize pathology: Obliteration of the right cardiac border occurs when a lesion in the right middle lobe is present, as the lobe lies adjacent to the right atrium. The loss of normal heart-lung interface suggests consolidation, atelectasis, or mass in the right middle lobe . Lobar Localization: Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left. PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension. Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension. Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes. Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes. Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL. Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML. Silhouette Sign: Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border. Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph. The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette. Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung. Localization Using the Silhouette Sign Obliterated Cardiac Border Likely Affected Lobe Right cardiac border (Right atrium) Right Middle Lobe Right hemidiaphragm Right Lower Lobe Left cardiac border (Left ventricle) Lingula (Left Upper Lobe) Left hemidiaphragm Left Lower Lobe

questions.question: Comment on the diagnosis of CT chest shown below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Aortic dissection Explanation: The given CT shows an intimal tear in the aorta indicating an Aortic dissection. Aortic Dissection It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer and creating a false lumen. Clinical features: Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region Renal pain and renal failure Paraplegia Syncope Weakness Hypotension or shock Investigations: If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice. In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal. Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion. Signs of FALSE LUMEN: Cobweb Sign: Irregularities of False lumen Beak Sign: False lumen forms acute angle with True lumen: Pulmonary embolism (Option B): Filling Defect seen in Pulmonary artery IOC for PE: CT Angiography Cardiac Myxoma (Option C): Low annotating hypodense lesion on the posterior most chamber of the heart (Left Atrium) MC primary Benign cardiac tumor in adults. Aortic aneurysm (Option D): Involve either ascending aorta, thoracic aorta & abdominal aorta Represents localized dilation of the aorta; while an aneurysm may predispose to dissection, an intimal tear specifically indicates dissection. M/C cause for abdominal & thoracic aortic aneurysm: Atherosclerosis

questions.question: A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure. The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) MUGA Explanation: Ejection fraction (EF) is a critical parameter for differentiating heart failure with preserved EF (HFpEF) from heart failure with reduced EF (HFrEF). MUGA scan is a non-invasive nuclear imaging test that accurately calculates EF by analyzing the motion of the heart's ventricles using a radioactive tracer and a gamma camera. Purpose Scan types For Myocardial Perfusion Assess ischemia Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas. Thallium scan (Commonly used) (Option B) Tetrofosmin Sestamibi scan (Option D) For Myocardial Infarction Assess infarct Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized. 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan. For Ventricular Function Evaluate ejection fraction MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography) Radiolabeled RBCs are used Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI For Myocardial Viability Assess the viability of myocardium PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. (Option C) Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan. Perfusion Agents :N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride. Metabolism Agent : FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism. No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct. FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment. Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation ). Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue . Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable. Myocardial Viability

questions.question: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning CORADS? CORADS: COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

options.C: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
options.D: Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID- 19 Explanation: The COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CORADS) is a standardized system for assessing the probability of COVID-19 pneumonia based on CT findings. CORADS-5 indicates a very high level of suspicion for COVID-19 , with features such as bilateral ground-glass opacities, crazy paving patterns, and subpleural involvement—typical imaging findings in COVID-19 pneumonia. CO-RADS (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System): Aspect Details Purpose Categorical assessment of chest CT scans for suspected COVID-19 cases Scale CO-RADS 1 (very low suspicion) to CO-RADS 5 (very high suspicion) Interobserver Agreement Moderate to substantial agreement among radiologists Discriminatory Power High accuracy in diagnosing COVID-19 Utility & Reliability Effective and standardized reporting tool CO-RADS-AI AI-based tool that automates CO-RADS scoring and CT severity assessment Accuracy Effective in high-prevalence areas Combination with Other Findings AUC value of 0.89 when used with RT-PCR and clinical findings CORADS-0 indicates normal lung (option A): This is incorrect because CORADS-0 is used when the scan is technically insufficient or of poor quality, and not for a normal lung.\ Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19 (option C): This is incorrect because pleural thickening is not a typical finding in COVID-19 pneumonia; it is more common in chronic lung diseases or other infections. Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19 (option D): This is incorrect because lobar consolidation is more typical of bacterial pneumonia, whereas COVID-19 pneumonia usually shows patchy ground-glass opacities and consolidation. Reference: Automated Assessment of CO-RADS and Chest CT Severity Scores in Patients with Suspected COVID-19 Using Artificial Intelligence CO-RADS – A categorical CT assessment scheme for patients with suspected COVID-19: definition and evaluation - PMC Diagnostic performance and interobserver agreement of CO-RADS: evaluation of classification in radiology practice - PMC

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features presented with a sudden onset of breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: sudden-onset breathlessness strongly suggests spontaneous pneumothorax , which is commonly seen in Marfan syndrome due to underlying connective tissue defects. Radiological Features (Chest X-ray): Absent lung markings in the affected area Hyperlucency due to air accumulation Collapsed lung margin Mediastinal shift (in tension pneumothorax) The classic association of Marfan syndrome with spontaneous pneumothorax makes this the most likely diagnosis. Spontaneous Pneumothorax Spontaneous pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space without trauma. It is classified into: Type Features Primary No underlying lung disease, seen in tall, thin males (e.g., Marfan syndrome) Secondary Occurs in patients with underlying lung disease (e.g., COPD, tuberculosis) Tension Pneumothorax Air trapping leads to mediastinal shift , requiring emergency intervention Diagnosis: Confirmed by chest X-ray or CT scan . Management: Needle decompression for tension pneumothorax, followed by chest tube insertion for drainage. Radiological findings in pneumothorax Visible visceral pleural edge as a thin white line. Absent lung markings peripheral to this line. The affected side is radiolucent compared to the opposite side. Collapsed lung on the affected side. Contralateral mediastinal shift especially in massive pneumothoraces (tension pneumothorax). The diaphragm of the affected side is pushed down. The supine radiograph shows the

questions.question: Plethoric lung fields are seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) TAPVC Explanation: Plethoric lung fields are seen on chest X-ray when there is increased pulmonary blood flow. In TAPVC, pulmonary veins connect abnormally to the systemic venous circulation instead of the left atrium. This results in mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and congestion. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) Pathology Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion Sites of venous connection Supracardiac- superior vena cava (Most common) Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium Infracardiac Mixed Clinical presentation Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure With ASD- wide and split S2 Chest X-ray Snowman or figure-8 configuration in supracardiac TAPVC Treatment Surgery No indication for prostaglandins (Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion) Incorrect Options: Tricuspid atresia (Option B): is a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is completely closed or absent. It leads to cyanosis and reduced pulmonary blood flow, which is typically associated with diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields. Ebstein anomaly (Option C): is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal tricuspid valve anatomy. It results in a displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle, causing right atrial enlargement. Plethoric lung fields are not a characteristic radiological finding associated with this condition. TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot) (Option D): TOF is a congenital heart defect characterized by four specific abnormalities in the heart's structure. It includes a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. While TOF can result in a right-to-left shunt and cyanosis, it typically leads to reduced pulmonary blood flow and diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields.

questions.question: A patient with a history of breast cancer underwent Cobalt-60 radiotherapy. She now presents with respiratory distress, and imaging shows haziness in the left lung. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: is a known risk factor for radiation pneumonitis . Symptoms of Respiratory Distress: Radiation pneumonitis typically presents weeks to months after radiotherapy with dyspnea, dry cough, and low-grade fever . Imaging Findings (Haziness in Left Lung): Chest X-ray or CT often shows hazy opacities in the irradiated lung field , which is characteristic of radiation-induced lung injury. Radiation Pneumonitis Feature Details Cause Radiation damage to lung tissue, commonly from breast, lung, or esophageal cancer radiotherapy Onset 4-12 weeks post-radiotherapy Symptoms Dry cough, dyspnea, low-grade fever, chest pain Imaging Hazy opacities in the irradiated lung field (CT: ground-glass opacities, consolidation) Treatment Corticosteroids (prednisone), supportive care Recurrence of Breast Cancer (Option B): Incorrect because recurrence usually presents with lung nodules or pleural effusion , not diffuse haziness. Pulmonary Embolism (Option C): Incorrect because PE typically presents with sudden pleuritic chest pain , clear lung fields on X-ray , and wedge-shaped infarcts on CT pulmonary angiography . Infective Pneumonia (Option D): Incorrect because pneumonia usually presents with fever,

questions.question: The appearance of USG at saphenofemoral junction, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein is called as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mickey Mouse sign Explanation: The appearance of the ultrasound (USG) at the saphenofemoral junction, showing the common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein, is referred to as the Mickey Mouse sign. In the Mickey Mouse sign, the common femoral vein represents the face of Mickey Mouse, and the common femoral artery and great saphenous vein represent the ears. This visual resemblance to the iconic Disney character gives rise to the term "Mickey Mouse sign." Radiological Sign Description Associated Pathology Classic Mickey Mouse Sign Refers to the appearance of bilateral cranial nerve (CN) VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Mickey Mouse's head. Acoustic neuroma Reverse Mickey Mouse Sign The reverse of the classic Mickey Mouse sign, where bilateral CN V and CN VI enhancement resemble Mickey Mouse's head. Trigeminal schwannoma Minnie Mouse Sign Refers to unilateral CN VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Minnie Mouse's head. Facial nerve schwannoma or hemangioma Mickey Mouse Ears Sign Describes bilateral globus pallidus hyperintensity on brain MRI, resembling the shape of Mickey Mouse's ears. Wilson’s disease or Carbon monoxide poisoning Mickey Mouse Glove Sign Characterized by symmetric calcification of basal ganglia structures on brain CT, resembling a Mickey Mouse glove. Fahr’s syndrome or Wilson’s disease String sign (Option B): is a term used in other medical imaging modalities, such as barium studies or endoscopy, to describe a thin, elongated appearance of a narrowed or strictured segment of the gastrointestinal tract. Tillaux sign (Option C): is a radiological finding observed in Salter-Harris III fractures of the distal tibia. It refers to the lateral displacement of the epiphysis in relation to the tibial metaphysis. Stamers sign (Option D): Stamers sign is not a recognized medical term or radiological finding in the context of the saphenofemoral junction or ultrasound imaging.

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a 36-year-old farmer who presented with a cough, chest pain lasting one week, fatigue persisting for a month, and a chest x-ray revealing the image provided below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hydatid cyst Explanation: The image shows ‘Water lily sign’ (partially fluid-filled cyst with a floating endocyst) seen in hydatid cyst. Hydatid cyst Echinococcus granulosus (most common), E. multilocularis, and E. vogeli. Cause cystic lesions primarily in the liver and lungs . Dogs are the primary reservoir ; mammals serve as intermediate hosts . Unilocular Cystic Echinococcosis (E. granulosus): Pulmonary Involvement Can occur through diaphragm invasion or hematogenous spread . Lungs are the second most common site for hematogenous spread in adults and the primary site in children . Radiographic Findings : Uncomplicated cysts appear as thin-walled, round or oval masses with low-attenuation contents and a thin enhancing wall, up to 10 cm in size. Signs of Impending Rupture : Meniscus Sign : Air lucency between the pericyst and laminated membranes when cyst communicates with bronchioles. Signs Associated with Cyst Rupture : Cumbo Sign or Onion Peel Sign : Indicates that the endocyst has shrunk and ruptured due to increasing air. Curvilinear membrane outlined by air both inside the endocyst and a crescent of air between the endocyst and pericyst. Water Lily Sign : Also known as the camalote sign. Indicates that the endocyst membrane is detached, it will appear as a floating curvilinear structure ( fluid-filled cyst ) within an intact pericyst. This gives the appearance of a floating water lily. Mass Within the Cavity : An endocyst floating in a completely fluid-filled cyst.

questions.question: The structure marked with arrowhead is?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Trachea Explanation: The arrowhead in the X-ray points to a midline, air-filled tubular structure. Based on the image, the structure is most consistent with the trachea . Normal Chest X Rays with marking: Incorrect Options: Esophagus (Option A): The esophagus is posterior to the trachea It does not appear as a dark, air-filled structure like the trachea in this image. Pulmonary artery (Option B): The pulmonary arteries are part of the hilar structures in the lungs. They are located lateral to the trachea and do not appear as a straight, air-filled structure on a chest X-ray. Left atrium (Option D): T he left atrium is part of the heart and is located in the lower part of the mediastinum. It is not a tubular structure and cannot appear as an air-filled space.

questions.question: A patient presented with complaints with dyspnoea. The shown X-ray is suggestive of:-
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- Exudative pleural effusion Explanation: Based on the description provided, the X-ray findings include obliteration of the costophrenic angle (CP angle) and an upward concave curve on the left side of the lung. These findings are suggestive of a pleural effusion. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Small Pleural Fluid: Often undetectable on PA chest x-rays; ultrasound or CT can detect small subpulmonary effusions. Effusion Progression: Blunting of costophrenic angles starts at 200-500 mL. Classic signs include opacification of the lower chest with a concave superior margin. Massive Effusions: 1000 mL reaches the fourth anterior rib; cause dense opacification of the hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift. Diaphragmatic inversion may occur. Lateral decubitus X-rays: Increase sensitivity for small effusions as the pleural fluid moves with gravity and the lung effectively floats on the effusion. Subpulmonary Effusions: Appear as a "high hemidiaphragm" on x-rays, with an unusual contour that peaks laterally than usual. Ultrasound or CT confirms the diagnosis. In an upright PA view, the meniscus sign indicates the presence of a significant amount of pleural fluid, typically exceeding 200 mL and blunting the costophrenic angle. Loculated (encysted, encapsulated) pleural fluid: Fluid can loculate between visceral pleural layers in fissures or between visceral and parietal layers, often against the chest wall. Commonly results from adhesions. Xray shows D sign. Consolidation (Option A): This would show more distinct lung tissue involvement with air bronchograms and possible increased density, but it wouldn’t obliterate the costophrenic angle as seen in pleural effusion.

questions.question: Identify the sign:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A- Seashore sign Explanation: The Seashore sign is an M ultrasound sign where pleural and structures above appear as horizontal echogenic (bright) lines, while the underlying lung shows a grainy or sandy texture, which represents lung sliding. This is commonly seen in normal lungs with adequate ventilation, differentiating lung sliding from pneumothorax where lung sliding is absent. Sea-shore sign: On M-mode images, lung sliding manifests as the sea-shore sign, where the pleura and structures above appear as horizontal echogenic lines . The underlying lung presents a grainy or sandy texture. The stratified appearance above the pleural line is due to the motionless chest wall , resembling sea waves , while below the pleural line, the lung movement creates a sandy pattern , akin to the shore . Barcode/stratosphere sign: (Option B, C) In cases where lung sliding is absent , M-mode images show uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign. The lack of a grainy or sandy appearance in these images indicates the absence of motion . The stratosphere sign suggests that pneumothorax may be a likely cause. Lung point sign: The border between the sliding lung and pneumothorax is referred to as the "lung point" sign. This sign can assist in estimating the size of the pneumothorax . It is important to note that the lung point is only observable if part of the lung is still in contact with the chest wall . The lung point sign is not present in large pneumothoraces . Deep sulcus sign (Option D): An X-ray sign where the costophrenic angle appears deepened in pneumothorax

questions.question: A 35-year-old male patient presented with a productive cough. He is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- Consolidation Explanation: Consolidation refers to a condition in which the air spaces in the lungs fill with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the loss of normal air-filled lung tissue. On chest X-ray (CXR), consolidation appears as an area of increased opacity due to the filling of alveoli with fluid, pus, or other substances. In this case, the patient's chronic smoking and alcoholism increase the risk of developing respiratory infections. CXR Radiological Findings Associated Diseases Consolidation Pneumonia, Lung abscess Infiltrates Pulmonary edema, ARDS Atelectasis Obstructive lung disease, Pneumothorax Blunting of the Costophrenic Angle Pleural effusion, Empyema Cavity Tuberculosis, Lung abscess Nodule/mass Lung cancer, Pulmonary metastasis Ground-glass opacities Interstitial lung diseases (e.g., Pulmonary fibrosis, Pneumoconiosis) Honeycombing Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, End-stage interstitial lung disease Air bronchograms Consolidation, Alveolar processes Mediastinal shift Pneumothorax, Large pleural effusion, Mediastinal mass Abscess (Option A): They would typically appear as a cavity with an air-fluid level, which is not mentioned here. Cavity filled with air & fluid Cavity (Option C): Cavities have distinct air-fluid levels and thin or thick walls, seen in tuberculosis. Pleural effusion (Option D): This would present with obliteration of the costophrenic angle and/or meniscus sign, not described in this case.

questions.question: A patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration. The chest X-ray has been shown below. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Pneumococcus Explanation: The chest X-ray showed features of round pneumonia and the patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration, the likely causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Round pneumonia is a term used to describe a specific radiographic appearance of pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumonia. Disease Radiological Findings Staphylococcal Pneumonia (Option D) Air Bronchogram Mycoplasma Pneumonia Reticulonodular Markings Klebsiella Pneumonia Bulging Fissure Sign Legionella Pneumonia Bilateral Multifocal Consolidation Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia Reticular Shadows and multiple cysts more often in the upper part of the lungs. Lung Abscess Air-Fluid Level Aspergilloma Fungal ball/ Monad sign Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis Gloved-Finger Sign Invasive Aspergillosis Air-Crescent Sign/ Halo sign Adenoid Hypertrophy Adenoid Enlargement Acute Epiglottitis Thumb Sign Croup (Parainfluenza) (Option B) Steeple Sign Mucormycosis Reverse halo sign/Bird nest sign/Atoll sign Haemophilus influenzae (Option A) Patchy or segmental consolidation, may have pleural effusion

questions.question: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.explanation: lung. It refers to the appearance of a wavy, irregular border between the aerated lung and the fluid-filled or consolidated lung tissue. This sign is observed in the context of pulmonary edema or consolidation. Incorrect Options: Option A . Stratosphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging. Also known as barcode sign. If lung sliding is absent , it will appear on the M-mode images as uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or the barcode sign Option C . Troposphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging. There is nothing like that Option D. Mirror image artifact: This refers to an artifact where a structure appears duplicated or mirrored in the ultrasound image, and it is not specific to lung imaging.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with a history of low-grade fever and cough. Based on the provided Chest X-ray image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Miliary TB Explanation: Miliary mottling refers to opacities that resemble millet seeds and are seen in the above Chest X-ray, which are seen in miliary TB (not specific) It can also be seen in metastasis, pulmonary hemosiderosis, or silicosis. Miliary tuberculosis (TB): Severe and disseminated form of tuberculosis (TB), a condition arising from Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Results from hematogenous spread of the infection. It can occur in both primary and post-primary pulmonary TB (PTB). Clinically significant miliary TB affects 1% to 7% of all TB cases. Initial chest X-ray (CXR) may appear normal; hyperinflation can be the earliest sign. Typical radiographic findings: Small, discrete nodules measuring 1-2 mm in diameter, distributed evenly throughout both lungs. Tree-in-bud nodules are poorly defined and have a patchy distribution. Chest CT: More sensitive than radiographs and reveals a random distribution of miliary nodules. These nodules may enlarge and coalesce, forming focal or diffuse consolidation. They resolve slowly over 2-6 months with adequate treatment, typically without causing scarring or calcification. Miliary nodules signify active infection and are associated with a poor prognosis. Lung cancer (Option A): Typically presents as a solitary nodule or mass, not diffuse tiny nodules. ARDS (Option C): This would show bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates, not miliary nodules. Aspergilloma (Option D): Usually seen as a solid mass (fungus ball) in a pre-existing cavity, not diffuse nodules. A radiologic finding is the air crescent sign , a crescent-shaped radiolucency representing air surrounding the fungus ball within the cavity.

questions.question: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia? 1. Interlobular septations 2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation 3. Pleural effusion 4. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation: interlobular septa due to inflammation or oedema, particularly in invasive fungal infections like mucormycosis or aspergillosis. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation (2): A hallmark of angioinvasive fungal infections (e.g., Aspergillus ) is peripheral, wedge-shaped areas of consolidation due to vascular infarction. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (4): Known as the "halo sign," this finding is common in invasive aspergillosis, where necrosis leads to cavitation surrounded by haemorrhage. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) • ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis. • It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus Radiographic Findings : • Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes • Lobar collapse • Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape) • Occasional pulmonary cavitation Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball • Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities , • These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes . CT Characteristics : • Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity. • The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign . • The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility. Angioinvasive Aspergillosis • Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals, I Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries. I Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts. CT Findings : • Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. • The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis . • Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections. Pleural effusion (3): This is uncommon in fungal pneumonia and is not a typical feature. It is more often associated with bacterial pneumonia or empyema.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: characteristic of pulmonary edema . Diffuse bilateral infiltrates in a butterfly or bat-wing pattern are seen, which suggests pulmonary edema. Engorgement of pulmonary vessels and Kerley B lines (septal lines) are often present. The presence of a central distribution of opacities sparing the periphery is highly suggestive. Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema often shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette , indicating heart failure as the underlying cause. Pulmonary Edema Feature Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema Cause Left heart failure, volume overload ARDS, infections, sepsis, toxins X-ray Findings A-A lveolar oedema (Bat wings) B- Kerley B lines C-C ardiomegaly D-D ilated Upper lobe vessels E -Pleural E ffusion Diffuse alveolar infiltrates, normal heart size Symptoms Dyspnea, orthopnea, pink frothy sputum Severe hypoxia, respiratory distress Treatment Diuretics, nitrates, and oxygen treat CHF Oxygen, and ventilatory support, treat the underlying cause Xray findings of Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: Chest X-ray showing Batwing appearance due to Alveolar edema Chest X-ray showing Kerley B lines, Cardiomegaly, Dilated vessels of upper lobe and mild pleural effusion. Hydrothorax (Option B): Incorrect because hydrothorax refers to fluid in the pleural space (pleural effusion due to CHF, liver disease), which appears as a blunted costophrenic angle and fluid meniscus , not diffuse infiltrates. Pleural Effusion (Option C): Incorrect because pleural effusion appears as homogeneous opacity with meniscus sign rather than diffuse alveolar opacities. Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option D): Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis

questions.question: A 38-year-old patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice for the past month. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
options.B: Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.explanation: findings of a localized outpouching on the aorta are consistent with a saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch. The patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice, which suggests the involvement of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve—a phenomenon known as Cardiovocal Syndrome (Ortner syndrome). Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness that improves with rest. She also complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins in her thorax. Based on the CT scan image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: typically present as anterior mediastinal mass. Myasthenia gravis is commonly associated with thymomas. Dysphagia and engorged thoracic veins suggest compression of the esophagus and superior vena cava. The CT also shows an anterior mediastinal mass, which supports the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not associated with the given findings.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress and a history of recurrent respiratory infections. Based on the radiographs provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A 25-year-old patient presented with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase. He was stabilized after three days. What is the most common pathology associated with the chest X-ray obtained?
questions.explanation: acute pancreatitis (suggested by epigastric pain + elevated serum lipase ). ARDS is a known pulmonary complication of acute pancreatitis , especially in severe cases due to inflammatory cytokine release. ARDS typically develops within a few days of the primary illness and can be seen on chest X-ray as bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates without cardiomegaly. Abdominal Pathology Causing Pulmonary Complications Condition Primary Event Lung Complication Time of Onset Imaging Finding Acute pancreatitis Inflammation, enzyme release ARDS Within 24–72 hours Bilateral infiltrates (non-cardiogenic) Heart failure Volume overload Pulmonary edema Variable Bilateral perihilar haziness + cardiomegaly Pulmonary embolism Thrombus in pulmonary arteries Infarcts, pleural-based opacities Sudden onset Wedge-shaped infarcts on CXR/CT Miliary TB Disseminated TB infection Miliary nodules throughout lung Subacute/chronic Uniform millet-sized nodules Acute pulmonary edema (Option B): Incorrect because this usually shows perihilar bat-wing pattern and is associated with cardiac causes , which are not suggested here. Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option C): Incorrect as there is

questions.question: A patient presents with foul-smelling sputum, breathlessness, and fever. Based on the X-ray below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings suggest a lung abscess. Incorrect Options: Option B - Pneumothorax: It will appear black on X-ray. Option C - Pleural effusion: In the PA view, the fluid starts accumulating in the costophrenic angle (dependent part). So, blunting of the costophrenic angle is present. Option D - Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion will show water bottle configuration.

questions.question: A patient complains of difficulty breathing, and fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis Explanation: The X-Ray image is suggestive of Constrictive pericarditis and the clinical features are also consistent with Constrictive pericarditis. It is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restriction in the ventricular filling X-ray appearance: Egg in cup appearance IOC: CT scan Constrictive Pericarditis: Pathophysiology: Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling. Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction. Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing: Atrial hypertrophy Atrial dilation Atrial fibrillation (common). Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare). Examination Findings: Finding Description Elevated JVP with rapid y descent Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient. Fatigue Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands. Rapid, low-volume pulse Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse. Pericardial knock A loud early S3 from the thickened

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not a potential cause for the radiological finding shown below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Foreign body Explanation: The foreign body does not intrinsically cause a white-out hemithorax; it may lead to secondary effects (e.g., collapse), which would then result in the finding. However, as an independent cause, it is not directly responsible. Whiteout hemithorax/Opacified hemithorax Blackout hemithorax/Hyperlucent hemithorax This refers to when there is complete opacification of an entire hemithorax. Clinical information and other radiological findings are important to make a definite diagnosis. This refers to an entire hyperlucent hemithorax. It results from various congenital and acquired conditions of the pulmonary parenchyma, airway, pulmonary vasculature, pleural space, and chest wall. Differential diagnoses Differential diagnoses Atelectasis of the entire lung Large pleural effusion (Option C) Pneumonia of the entire lung Postpneumonectomy appearance Large pulmonary, pleural, or chest wall mass in diseases like Ewing sarcoma, mesothelioma Pulmonary hypoplasia or agenesis Consolidation (Option A) Collapse (Option B) Radiologic technique errors Emphysema (bullous emphysema) Asymmetric chest wall soft tissue due to conditions like: Poland syndrome Unilateral mastectomy Some professions like butchers, carpenters, etc Atrophy of trapezius muscle after radical neck dissection Extrapulmonary air collection in pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema Contralateral large pleural effusion (Pseudo hyperlucent appearance of opposite lung) Bronchial obstruction Foreign body in children Bronchial atresia Endobronchial tumor Broncholith Bronchiolitis obliterans in Swyer-James syndrome Congenital lobar hyperinflation Conditions affecting pulmonary vessels: Pulmonary

questions.question: A patient who has been treated for TB in the past now presented with hemoptysis. Make a diagnosis based on the given X-ray.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Aspergilloma Explanation: The above image shows the air crescent sign or the monod sign and along with the clinical presentation of the patient suggests aspergilloma. Aspergilloma is seen in conditions with pre-existing lung cavities, such as Tuberculosis. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis. It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus Radiographic Findings : Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes Lobar collapse Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape) Occasional pulmonary cavitation Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities , These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes . CT Characteristics : Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity. The mass is usually separated from the cavity

questions.question: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest x-ray, the following object is seen. Identify the object.

The patient has a history of fever and cough for the last 5 days. The examination findings show crepitations, and a chest X-ray is shown below. Based on these details, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?

options.A: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
options.C: Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.explanation: well-defined opacity in the right middle lobe, which is consistent with the description of pneumonia in the scenario. The loss of the right heart border indicates pathology in the right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe. Pneumonia is typically associated with fever, cough, and crepitations on examination, which match the clinical picture given in this question. The loss of clear demarcation between the surrounding structures and normal lung is called silhouette sign. Lobar Localization: Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left. PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension. Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension. Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes. Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes. Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL. Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML. Silhouette Sign: Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border. Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta

questions.question: Please identify the rib that is shown in the X-ray.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 3rd rib posterior part Explanation: 3rd rib posterior part : The posterior part of the rib is typically identified by its position relative to the spine and the more horizontal orientation in an X-ray, especially when taken from a lateral view. The posterior part of the rib will be closer to the vertebrae and typically appears more curved and parallel to the spine on the X-ray. The highlighted structure in the image is consistent with this description, which is why the 3rd rib posterior part is the correct answer. 3rd rib anterior part (option A) : Incorrect because the anterior part of the 3rd rib would be closer to the sternum, with a more forward and downward orientation on an X-ray. The posterior part is more visible in this case. 4th rib anterior part (option C) : Incorrect because the 4th rib would be located further down than the 3rd rib, and its anterior part would be closer to the sternum. This option doesn't match the positioning seen in the image. 1st rib anterior part (option D) : Incorrect because the 1st rib is positioned more superiorly, closer to the clavicle. Its anterior part would be located near the sternum, and this is not consistent with the rib shown in the image. Reference: Rib radiographs for trauma: useful or wasteful? - PubMed

questions.question: Hamman sign is seen in
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pneumomediastinum Explanation: Pneumomediastinum : Hamman sign is a characteristic physical finding heard on auscultation. It is described as a crunching sound or synchronous clicking sound with the heartbeat, often heard in the precordial area . It is typically associated with pneumomediastinum , where air is present in the mediastinal space, often due to esophageal rupture or trauma. The air in the mediastinum creates a distinctive sound when it moves with the heartbeats, producing the Hamman sign. Pneumomediastinum: Presence of free air around mediastinal structures. Common Causes: Blunt or penetrating trauma. Esophageal perforation. Recent interventions in the esophageal or tracheobronchial tree. Pulmonary infections. Gas-forming infections in the mediastinum. Cocaine inhalation. Extension of air from a pneumothorax. Hamman's crunch sign: Unusual, adventitious sound heard on auscultation of the chest. Radiographic Signs: Ring around the artery sign: Air around the pulmonary artery (usually the right) outlining the artery. Sail sign: Elevation of the thymus caused by air. Continuous diaphragm sign: Air trapped posterior to the pericardium, appearing as a continuous air collection on an AP projection Tubular artery sign: Air outlines the medial side of major aortic branches, with aerated lung outlining the lateral side. Double bronchial wall sign: Air adjacent to the bronchus highlights the bronchial wall. Naclerio V-sign: V-shaped air lucency in the left lower mediastinal area. Pneumoperitoneum (option A) : Incorrect because pneumoperitoneum refers to air in the peritoneal cavity , usually caused by gastrointestinal perforation. It does not typically produce the Hamman sign. Instead, it is more commonly detected through radiological imaging (e.g., abdominal X-ray) showing air under the diaphragm. Pneumopericardium (option B) : Incorrect because pneumopericardium is the presence of air in the pericardial sac around the heart, which may lead to cardiac tamponade . While it can cause a clinical presentation of chest pain or dyspnoea, it is not typically associated with the Hamman sign. Hydropneumothorax (option D) : Incorrect because hydropneumothorax refers to the accumulation of both air and fluid in the pleural cavity , commonly due to trauma or infection. While it may cause dyspnoea and chest pain , it does not produce the characteristic Hamman sign.

questions.question: A 47-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever, malaise, and productive cough. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? segment of the lower lobes

options.A: Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
options.B: Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia
options.C: Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy
options.D: Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia Explanation: The most common cause of community-acquired pyogenic pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus). The most common imaging pattern seen on a chest X-ray for pneumococcal pneumonia is lobar consolidation; meaning a homogeneous consolidation affecting one or more lobes of the lung Patchy infiltrates are not typical for pyogenic pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. Classification of Pneumonia Based on Imaging Pattern: Lobar Pneumonia: Unifocal consolidation, most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae . In children under 8 years, may appear as “Round Pneumonia” with ill-defined margins. Air bronchograms are common due to patent airways and minimal volume loss. Bronchopneumonia (Lobular Pneumonia): Multifocal distribution, centered around distal airways. Heterogeneous scattered opacities along airway course, coalescing in severe cases. Air bronchogram absent due to airway involvement. Atypical Pneumonia: Features distinct from lobar or bronchopneumonia (discussed in the table below). Causative Agent Specific Imaging Features Streptococcus pneumoniae Most common cause of community-acquired lobar pneumonia in adults. Staphylococcus aureus Common in debilitated patients / superinfection in influenza / secondary to IV drug abuse. Cavitation common in later radiographs. Pneumatoceles (seen in children during recovery phase). Klebsiella pneumoniae Occurs in elderly and alcoholics, usually involves the right upper lobe (RUL). Bulging of fissures due to increased involved lung volume. Legionnaire’s disease (Legionella pneumophila) Rapidly spreading pneumonia from contaminated water sources (ACs, coolers, showers). Also presents with diarrhea, mental confusion (hyponatremia), and shock. Actinomycosis Can mimic bronchogenic carcinoma. Soft tissue/bone involvement (periostitis) – key differentiating feature. CT: Peripheral homogeneous consolidation with central low attenuation and pleural thickening (diagnostic feature). Atypical pneumonia (Most common cause: Mycoplasma pneumoniae) Atypical organism (lacks cell walls, resistant to penicillins). Fine reticular/nodular shadows in perihilar region early, which may progress to consolidation (rare lobar involvement). WBC count usually normal. Presents with non-productive cough, absent/minimal sputum. Not aspiration-related. Common in poorly maintained air-conditioned areas. Other viral causes: Influenza A & B, RSV, Adenovirus, Chlamydia psittaci, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever). Varicella pneumonia Predominantly nodular opacities (5–10 mm). If persistent, may calcify, leading to miliary shadows on CXR. Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B): Mycoplasma pneumonia typically causes atypical pneumonia , with interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation. Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy (Option C): Lung cancer, especially small cell carcinoma and lymphoma , commonly presents with hilar lymphadenopathy along with parenchymal lung infiltrates. Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes (Option D): Aspiration pneumonia classically affects the dependent lung segments , particularly the posterior segment of the upper lobes and the superior segment of the lower lobes , especially in supine patients .

questions.question: Please identify the pathology present in the provided X-ray image.
questions.explanation: Air rises in the abdomen, and when it accumulates within the peritoneal cavity, it appears as a radiolucent area below the diaphragm. This creates a clear demarcation between the air-filled abdomen and the denser structures of the thoracic cavity. Incorrect Option: Option A: Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space, which is the space between the lungs and the chest wall. On a chest X-ray, pneumothorax typically appears as a dark area with absent lung markings at the lung periphery, indicating lung collapse. This is different from pneumoperitoneum, which involves the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity. Option C: Hydrothorax: Hydrothorax refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, hydrothorax appears as an opacity with blunted or obscured costophrenic angles, indicating fluid-filled lung spaces. It does not involve the presence of air as seen in pneumoperitoneum. Option D: Normal X-ray: A normal chest X-ray would not show any significant abnormalities. It would exhibit clear lung fields with normal heart size and mediastinal structures. In the case of pneumoperitoneum, the presence of free air under the diaphragm would be absent in a normal X-ray.

questions.question: What is your diagnosis based on the chest X-ray of a patient during the evaluation of PUO?
questions.explanation: tiny, widely scattered lesions appear throughout the lungs, resembling millet seeds . The chest X-ray image shown may display numerous small nodules diffusely distributed throughout the lung fields, indicating miliary tuberculosis. Incorrect options Option B: Pulmonary edema typically presents as an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the lungs. It is characterized by the presence of increased opacity or "whiteness" in the lung fields on a chest X-ray. T Option C: Necrobiotic nodules are a manifestation of various underlying conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, sarcoidosis, and other granulomatous diseases. These nodules appear as discrete, well-defined opacities on a chest X-ray. Option D: Tuberculoma refers to a localized tuberculous infection within the lung that typically presents as a single or few well-circumscribed nodules. Reference: .

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: characteristic appearance of the CT scan image with a dissection flap in the aorta, the correct diagnosis in this case is option b, "Aortic dissection." Incorrect Options: Option A: Pulmonary embolism- The symptoms typically include sudden onset chest pain, shortness of breath, and sometimes coughing up blood. However, the CT scan image provided in this case does not show typical findings consistent with pulmonary embolism. Option C: Aortic aneurysm- While aortic aneurysms can present with chest or abdominal pain, the CT scan image provided does not demonstrate the typical appearance of an aortic aneurysm. Option D: Myocardial infarction- It usually presents with symptoms such as severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and sweating. The CT scan image shown does not provide evidence of a myocardial infarction. Reference: .

questions.question: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.explanation: The superior vena cava is a large vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart. It is located in the upper part of the chest and is typically visible on a CT scan. Other options Option A: Descending aorta- This option is incorrect Option B: Ascending aorta- This option is incorrect Option D: Right pulmonary artery- This option is incorrect Reference: .

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of an 8-year-old child who has been experiencing a cough for the past 7 months, hemoptysis for 1 month, and fever for 4 days, as shown in the provided X-ray?
questions.explanation: consolidation. Consolidation refers to the solidification of lung tissue, usually due to the accumulation of inflammatory exudate or cellular infiltrates within the air spaces. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, fever, and in some cases, hemoptysis. Incorrect Options: Option A . Lung abscess: Lung abscess is characterized by a localized collection of pus within the lung parenchyma. It may present with similar symptoms as consolidation, but on an X-ray, it typically appears as a cavity or a well-defined round lesion with an air-fluid level. Option C . Hydatid cyst: Hydatid cyst is a parasitic infection caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus. It typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging, often containing daughter cysts. The X-ray provided does not show the characteristic features of a hydatid cyst. Option D . Thoracic duct malformation: Thoracic duct malformation refers to abnormalities in the structure or function of the thoracic duct, which is responsible for draining lymphatic fluid from the thoracic region. It does not appear to be relevant to the given history and X-ray findings. Reference: .

questions.question: For the diagnosis of all lung carcinomas, a thorax CECT is necessary. However, in which of the following scenarios is MRI considered beneficial?
questions.explanation: is a type of lung cancer that occurs in the upper part of the lung, typically involving the lung apex, adjacent chest wall, and nearby structures. This type of tumor is often associated with specific symptoms such as shoulder pain, arm weakness, and Horner's syndrome (a group of symptoms caused by damage to the sympathetic nerves). In the case of Pancoast tumor, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is useful for evaluation and diagnosis. MRI provides detailed images of soft tissues and can help visualize the extent of tumor involvement in the chest wall, surrounding structures, and nerves. It helps in determining the local spread and involvement of adjacent structures, aiding in treatment planning. Incorrect options: Option A . Small cell lung carcinoma: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) of the thorax is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating small cell lung carcinoma, as it provides detailed information about the tumor size, location, and potential metastasis. Option B . Adenocarcinoma: CECT thorax is commonly used for the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, as it helps in assessing the tumor size, location, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis. OptionC . Carcinoid: CECT thorax is the primary imaging modality used for evaluating carcinoid tumors, as it aids in determining the tumor location, size, and potential metastasis.

questions.question: Based on the provided X-ray, identify the likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation: the peritoneal cavity, which is the space within the abdomen that contains organs such as the stomach, intestines, and liver. On an X-ray, the pneumoperitoneum may appear as air under the diaphragm or a distinct "free air" sign. It is often associated with conditions such as perforated viscus (e.g., perforated bowel) or abdominal trauma. incorrect Options: Option A . Subdiaphragmatic abscess: A subdiaphragmatic abscess refers to an infection or collection of pus located below the diaphragm, usually in the abdominal cavity. It is typically not visualized on a standard chest X-ray and may require additional imaging modalities such as ultrasound or CT scan for diagnosis. Option B. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax is the presence of air or gas in the pleural cavity, the space between the lungs and the chest wall. It can be seen on a chest X-ray as a dark area with collapsed lung tissue. However, without seeing the actual X-ray, it is difficult to determine if this is the correct diagnosis. Option D . Intestinal obstruction: Intestinal obstruction occurs when there is a blockage in the normal flow of the intestinal contents. It can be caused by various factors such as adhesions, hernias, tumors, or volvulus. On an X-ray, findings may include dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels, although the specific features depend on the location and cause of the obstruction.

questions.question: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows an air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Consolidation Air bronchogram is a radiologic sign where air-filled bronchi are made visible by the surrounding consolidated alveoli (which are fluid- or pus-filled). This occurs when the alveoli are opacified (e.g., with pus, fluid, or blood), but the bronchi remain air-filled , creating the appearance of branching lucent structures within a dense opacity . Air Bronchogram Sign and Chest Radiographic Diagnosis Feature Air Bronchogram Sign Definition Lucent air-filled bronchi visible against consolidated lung Seen in Consolidation , pulmonary edema, ARDS, some tumors Absent in Pleural effusion, atelectasis with bronchial obstruction Most classical cause Lobar pneumonia (consolidation) Pleural effusion (Option A): Incorrect because effusion occurs in the pleural space , and the fluid obscures lung markings and airways , making air bronchograms absent . Hilar lymphadenopathy (Option C): Incorrect because lymphadenopathy causes mass-like opacities in the hilum , not diffuse alveolar filling, so no air bronchogram is seen. Bronchiectasis (Option D): Incorrect because bronchiectasis involves dilated bronchi , not alveolar filling. It may show a "tram-track" appearance but not air bronchograms . Reference: .http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/1720690 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6893008/

questions.question: Pick out the diagnosis.
questions.explanation: neck region. It is a congenital anomaly and occurs in a small percentage of the population. A cervical rib can potentially compress nearby structures, such as nerves or blood vessels, leading to various symptoms including neck pain, shoulder pain, arm pain, and numbness or weakness in the affected arm. The presence of a cervical rib can be evaluated using imaging studies like X-rays or CT scans. Incorrect Options: Option A . Costochondritis: Costochondritis refers to the inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the sternum (breastbone). It typically causes localized chest pain and tenderness, which may worsen with movement or deep breathing. The pain is often sharp and can be mistaken for a heart-related condition. However, costochondritis does not involve any structural abnormalities of the ribs or vertebral column. Option B . Spondylolisthesis: Spondylolisthesis is a condition in which one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. It commonly occurs in the lumbar spine (lower back) and can result in lower back pain, radiating leg pain, and neurologic symptoms if nerve compression occurs. It does not specifically involve the ribs or the presence of a cervical rib. Option D . Rib fracture: A rib fracture refers to a break or cracks in one or more of the ribs. It typically occurs due to trauma or direct impact on the chest. Rib fractures can cause localized chest pain that worsens with deep breathing, coughing, or movement. Diagnosis is usually confirmed through imaging, such as an X-ray or CT scan, which may reveal the fracture line

questions.question: The patient presented with dyspnea and the X-ray indicates:
questions.explanation: costophrenic angle ( CP angle) and an upward concave curve on the left side of the lung. These findings are suggestive of a pleural effusion. Incorrect options Option A : Consolidation - Consolidation refers to the filling of airspaces in the lungs with fluid or other substances, typically seen as opacities on an X-ray. The described findings do not correspond to consolidation. Option C : Pneumothorax - Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space, which can cause lung collapse. The described findings are not characteristic of a pneumothorax. Option D : Hydropneumothorax - Hydropneumothorax refers to the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space. While the presence of fluid is suggested by the X-ray findings, there is no mention of air in the pleural space.

questions.question: What is the structure indicated by the arrowhead in the image provided?
questions.explanation: structure located in the midline of the chest . It runs anteriorly to the esophagus and posteriorly to the heart . It is marked by the arrowhead in the image. Incorrect options Option A : Esophagus - The esophagus is located posteriorly to the trachea and is not visible in this lateral view. Option B : Pulmonary artery - The pulmonary artery is not visible in this particular view and is typically seen in other views such as the frontal or PA view. Option D : Left atrium - The left atrium is a cardiac structure and is not visualized in a chest X-ray. Reference: .

questions.question: A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure . The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction ?
questions.explanation: ejection fraction by tracking the movement of radioactive tracer-labeled red blood cells in the heart. It provides quantitative information about the heart's pumping function, allowing for the determination of HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Incorrect options: Option B . SPECT using thallium 201: This option is incorrect. SPECT (Single-Photon Emission Computed Tomography) using thallium 201 is a myocardial perfusion imaging technique used to assess blood flow to the heart muscle. It is not primarily used for the calculation of ejection fraction. Option C . PET myocardial perfusion imaging: This option is incorrect. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) myocardial perfusion imaging is another technique used to assess blood flow to the heart. While it provides valuable information about myocardial perfusion, it is not the primary method for calculating ejection fraction. Option D . Sestamibi scan with pharmacological stress: This option is incorrect. A sestamibi scan with pharmacological stress is a nuclear medicine imaging technique used to evaluate myocardial perfusion under stress conditions. It is not the primary method for determining ejection fraction.

questions.question: Please provide your analysis of the diagnosis based on the CT scan of the chest displayed below.
questions.explanation: Incorrect Options Option B: SADDLE EMBOLUS: PULMONARY EMBOLISM Filling Defect seen in Pulmonary artery IOC for PE: CT Angiography Option C. Cardiac Myxoma: Low annotating hypodense lesion on the posterior most chamber of the heart (Left Atrium) MC primary Benign cardiac tumor in adults. Option D. Aortic aneurysm: Involve either ascending aorta, thoracic aorta & abdominal aorta M/C cause for abdominal & thoracic aortic aneurysm – Atherosclerosis

questions.question: A patient has come in with a combination of fever, cough, and expectoration. The provided image displays the chest X-ray. What is the probable infectious agent responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: presented with fever and cough with expectoration, the likely causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae . Round pneumonia is a term used to describe a specific radiographic appearance of pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumonia. Incorrect Options: Option A. Hemophilus influenza: Hemophilus influenzae is a bacterium that can cause respiratory infections, including pneumonia. However, it is less commonly associated with the specific radiographic appearance of round pneumonia seen in the chest X-ray described. Option B. Parainfluenza virus: Parainfluenza virus is a common respiratory virus that can cause upper respiratory tract infections, such as croup. While it can lead to pneumonia in some cases, it is not typically associated with the specific radiographic findings of round pneumonia. Option D . S. aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause a wide range of infections, including respiratory tract infections. While it can cause pneumonia, the radiographic findings associated with S. aureus pneumonia are not typically described as round pneumonia. Instead, S. aureus pneumonia may present with features such as lobar consolidation or abscess formation.

questions.question: What could be the probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old male patient who has a history of chronic smoking and alcoholism, and is currently experiencing a productive cough? The provided image displays the chest X-ray for reference.
questions.explanation: with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the loss of normal air-filled lung tissue. It is commonly associated with lung infections such as pneumonia. In this case, the patient's chronic smoking and alcoholism increase the risk of developing respiratory infections. Incorrect options: Option A. Abscess: An abscess is a localized collection of pus within the lung tissue. It typically presents with symptoms such as fever, productive cough, and chest pain. While abscesses can occur in the lungs, they are less likely in this case since the CXR findings do not show a clear circumscribed cavity. Option C. Cavity: A cavity refers to a hollow space within the lung that is often formed as a result of necrotizing lung infections, such as tuberculosis. Cavity formation is characterized by the presence of a well-defined, air-filled space within the lung parenchyma. The provided information and CXR image do not strongly suggest the presence of a cavity. Option D. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. It typically presents with symptoms such as shortness of breath and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The CXR image does not indicate the presence of pleural effusion.

questions.question: Identify the sign :
questions.explanation: divides the image in half: The motionless portion above the pleural line creates horizontal 'waves,' and the sliding line below it creates granular pattern, the 'sand' . It is commonly associated with pulmonary fibrosis. Lung sliding seen on the M (motion) mode images appears as the sea-shore sign in which the pleura and the overlying structures appear as horizontal echogenic lines, while the underlying lung gives a grainy/sandy appearance. Incorrect options: Option B. Barcode sign: This term is not commonly used in medical imaging, and there is no specific radiological sign associated with it. Option C. Stratosphere sign : This term is not commonly used in medical imaging, and there is no specific radiological sign associated with it. Option D. Deep sulcus sign: This option is incorrect

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of a 74-year-old man, who comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of substantial unintentional weight loss, lack of appetite, and iron deficiency anemia, after a chest x-ray was performed and the results are provided below?
questions.explanation: be seen in different types of malignancies. Cannonball Metastasis is seen in choriocarcinoma because of the rich vascular supply, due to which metastasis occurs via the vascular route to the lungs. These cannonball metastases appear on chest X-rays as multiple white opacities like the fire of cannonballs. All these white opacities represent metastatic deposits. White opacities are clearly observed in the given X-ray, indicating option c as the correct choice. Incorrect Options: Option A: Bronchogenic Carcinoma is associated with increased vascularity and mass in the lung that may abut the vessels, and it may be associated with central necrosis and cavitation. It can also be associated with hypercalcemia and calcification deposits in the lungs. So, the X-ray shows central necrosis, cavitation, and hypercalcemia in a patient, which is not observed in the given case. Therefore, option A is an

questions.question: What is the subject matter of the X-ray image below?
questions.explanation: obliteration of the left costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung noted tracking along the CP angle and lateral chest wall. Incorrect Options: Option A - Tension Pneumothorax: It has air filling in the pleural cavity causing compression over lung parenchyma resulting in a Visceral pleural line sign which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice. Option B - Emphysema: It would show air trapping along with hyperinflation of alveoli resulting in decreased opacity and increased translucency with hyper-inflated lungs, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice. Option D - Bronchiectasis: It is associated with a signet ring sign along with dilated central and peripheral airways, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice. Reference: .
